column12: Has escaped from cultivation and has become widespread as a weed in the tropics; dead-heading plants to prevent seeding can enhance longevity; notably resistant to honey fungus
column13: Roasted seeds are eaten; all parts contain mmucilage which are responsible for healing and soothing properties; juice of leaves is demulcent and diuretic and can be used to treat fever, colic, clean wounds/ulcers; leaf or seed paste can be applied for wounds, boils, ulcers; seeds are laxatives and can be used for hemorrhoids and cough; infusion of the root can be used as treatment for leprosy and can be taken internally as cooling remedy for coughs/fevers; leaves powder decoction which can be used twice a day to treat piles; should be avoided by pregnant women and lactating mothers

column13: used to treat cold and cough, though it is advised to be used cautiously by pregnant women. The fruits are eaten raw, preserved, or unripe with salt, and the seeds are consumed raw as a snack. Medicinally, the plant is used to address chronic fatigue, digestive issues, diarrhoea, bronchitis, pharyngitis, anaemia, irritability, insomnia, nervous exhaustion, night sweats, palpitations, and excessive perspiration. The roots treat dyspepsia and fevers, while the leaves help relieve cough, asthma, boils, and impetigo, and are sometimes applied for hair growth or used as a plaster for urinary difficulties

column7: Tropical & subtropical climates; Found up to 1,100 m; Grows best where daytime temperatures are 20–30°C (tolerates 10–35°C); Prefers mean annual rainfall 1,000–1,400 mm (tolerates 900–1,500 mm); Seasonal rainfall regions
column8: Rich, well-drained soils; pH 5.5–7 preferred; tolerates pH 5–8
column12: Can become weedy when growing in open and disturbed ground; has often escaped from cultivation and is classified as "invasive" in many pacific islands; best to cut back the stems to about 15cm long in the spring even if they have not been killed back by frost or a dry season and this will ensure an abundance of new growth and plenty of flowers in the summer
column13: Used widely for edible, medicinal, aromatic, and practical purposes: young leaves and shoots cooked as vegetables or used in soups and sugar clarification; unripe seedpods cooked like okra; seeds cooked, roasted, or used as flavouring in liqueurs, coffee, baked goods, sweets, ice cream, and soft drinks; root also consumed. Seeds used medicinally as diuretic, demulcent, stomachic, stimulant, antiseptic, antispasmodic, cooling, tonic, carminative, aphrodisiac, nervine, and breath sweetener; seed emulsions soothe digestive spasms; pulverized seeds used for prickly heat; crushed seeds mixed with oil rubbed on feverish patients; musk-scented seeds used for dental cavities and bad breath; seeds recommended for sexually transmitted diseases; root powder taken once daily for 40 days to treat male impotence and female leucorrhoea, with caution advised during general weakness and pregnancy. Roots and leaves used in decoctions for gonorrhoea and rheumatism; grated roots applied to nail-pricks and thorn-pricks; macerated in rum as rub for fevers; leaves used as anti-inflammatory and febrifuge poultice for headaches; leaves and flowers applied to scabies and swellings; bark paste applied to cuts, wounds, and sprains; plant used as antivenom and diuretic. Essential oils used in aromatherapy for depression, anxiety, cramps, circulation issues, and aching joints, and in perfumery, cosmetics, tobacco, incense, and flavouring. Seed oil valued for its fatty acid composition; seeds used to perfume hair, repel insects in stored clothes, burn as incense, and make incense sticks. Plant, flower, and seed extracts used in commercial cosmetic products (masking agent, perfume, skin conditioner). Fibre from stem bark used for ropes and sails; root mucilage used for sizing paper; leaves used as parcel wrappers.

column7: Grows in open dry places up to 2,000 m (Nepal); found in secondary regrowth, forest edges, thickets, grasslands, trails, seasonal swamps, dried watercourses up to 3,000 m (Tanzania); in eastern Africa occurs where mean annual rainfall is 700-1,300 mm
column8: Fertile soil
column12: Indicator of soil fertility; seeds stick to fur/clothing, aiding natural spread; has escaped cultivation and invasive on several Pacific Islands
column13: Used as a food, medicine, and utility plant: leaves cooked and used as a spinach substitute or mixed with other vegetables; leaves sometimes burnt to make vegetable salt; seeds cooked and eaten with milk to reduce hunger and used as famine food; roots and whole plant widely used medicinally for dropsy, rheumatism, stomach issues, cholera, skin diseases, rabies, diarrhoea, dysentery, boils, haemorrhoids, rheumatic pains, skin eruptions, scorpion stings, nervous disorders, hysteria, insect and snake bites; root juice used with Urena lobata and Psidium guajava bark for diarrhoea/dysentery; leaf decoction used for diarrhoea/dysentery; plant used as astringent, digestive, diuretic, laxative, purgative, stomachic; ash mixed with mustard oil and salt used as tooth powder to clean teeth, relieve pyorrhoea and toothache; dried twigs used as toothbrushes; ash rich in potash used to wash clothes and as alkali in dyeing; roots traditionally tied on the uterus during labor to ease delivery and removed immediately after birth to avoid complications

column7: Grows from cold temperate zones to tropics; best where daytime temperatures are 18–26°C; tolerates 4–30°C; dormant plant tolerates down to –25°C; prefers mean annual rainfall 700–2,000 mm; tolerates 430–4,200 mm
column8: Requires shallow water or very moist loamy soil; succeeds in a wide range of soils; prefers pH 5.5–6.5; tolerates 5–7.5
column10: Requires shallow water or very moist soil
column12: NaN
column13: A multipurpose plant used as food, medicine, incense, insect repellent, and material: rhizomes candied, eaten raw after removing bitterness, roasted as a vegetable, used as flavouring in cordials, beer, gin, liqueurs, vinegar, and tea; powdered rhizome used as a spice substitute for ginger, cinnamon, and nutmeg; young inflorescences eaten for sweetness; young leaves eaten raw or cooked and used to flavour custards; inner stem eaten raw as salad. Widely used in herbal medicine as aromatic stimulant, mild tonic, digestive remedy, Ayurvedic brain/nervous-system rejuvenator, and treatment for bronchitis, sinusitis, digestive disorders, anorexia, arthritis, cancer, convulsions, diarrhoea, epilepsy, and toothache; roots are anodyne, aphrodisiac, aromatic, carminative, diaphoretic, emmenagogue, expectorant, febrifuge, hallucinogenic, hypotensive, sedative, stimulant, stomachic, tonic, and vermifuge; small doses reduce stomach acidity while larger doses increase secretions; excessive doses may cause nausea, vomiting, or hallucinations due to asarones. Infusion of root can induce abortion; chewing the root used to kill taste for tobacco; external use for skin eruptions, rheumatic pains, neuralgia; rhizomes paste applied to forehead to cure headaches and used as a nervine tonic, with internal use recommended only after purification (Sodhana). Leaves used for basket-making, mats, and roof thatch; dried leaves and roots used as incense, strewing herb, mosquito repellent, and to scent linen cupboards; essential oil from rhizomes and leaves used in perfumery, food flavouring, aromatic vinegars, and as an insecticide and insect repellent effective against houseflies and rice weevils; whole plant can be dried and used to repel insects

column7: Grows in shady hill forests in India; occurs in forests, thickets, wooded ravines, rocky soils, and streambanks at 200-1,500 m (Guatemala)
column8: Typically rocky soil

column13: taken on an empty stomach to treat cholera and dysentery, with overdose potentially causing nausea.The fruit is used to treat breast swellings and elephantiasis, and a decoction of crushed fruits is drunk as an aphrodisiac. The dried fruit peel is used as an appetizer. The astringent bark is used for dysentery, diarrhoea, abdominal issues, and as a febrifuge. column13: flowers (20–40 ml) is taken once daily for up to a month to treat ovarian cysts. The flowers are also astringent and used to treat dysentery, often by mixing with honey into a confection, and they are considered helpful for menorrhagia.

column7: can be grown in warm temperate to tropical regions and succeeds from sea level to around 2,000 metres. It grows in areas with mean annual rainfall of 600–2,000 mm and can tolerate short-lived cold temperatures down to –10°C

column12: used in living fences, for marking land boundaries, for soil retention and moisture conservation, and is suitable for shelterbelts, windbreaks, and reforestation, especially in flood-affected or arid areas. It produces root suckers, which help with spread
column13: hot poultice of leaves is applied four times a day to relieve inflammation, and overdose may cause urine infection. The leaves are astringent, febrifuge, sedative, tonic, and vermifuge, and are used for joint swellings, gonorrhoea-related swellings, ulcers, sinus issues, and scrofulous sores. Leaf juice is used to repel insects and relieve headaches. A decoction of stems is used for burns and scalds. The dried fruit is vermifuge and used for angina, colds, coughs, and rheumatic difficulties. The fresh berries are pounded and used for paralysis and limb weakness. The root is expectorant, febrifuge, and tonic, used for colds and rheumatic ailments. The plant is also considered malarial-preventative and used for bacterial dysentery, with leaf extracts showing bactericidal and antitumor activity
